intro: Scleranthus perennis subsp. atlanticus, commonly known as the Atlantic annual sow-thistle, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of the northeastern United States and eastern Canada. It is an annual herb characterized by its erect, branched stems and alternate, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in loose clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils along shorelines and in disturbed areas, showcasing adaptations to coastal environments. Its botanical features make it an important component of coastal flora and a subject of ecological study.
